newsitem.title: CANADA: Geac jumps on stronger operating results.
newsitem.headline: Geac jumps on stronger operating results.

text.p: Geac Computer Corp Ltd jumped in active dealings on Friday as investors cheered unexpected gains in third quarter operating income, despite a substantial third quarter charge.
"The operating results and cash flow were way better," said Loewen Ondaatje McCutcheon analyst Mark Lawrence.
Third quarter operating income soared 49 percent to C$15.2 million from a year-earlier C$10.2 million before it took a C$121.4 million write-off for software, goodwill, inventory and fixed assets.
Shares in the computer firm rose 4.35 to 36.25 on volume of more than 170,000 shares on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

Geac, which reported a third quarter loss of C$3.71 a share compared to a year-earlier earnings of C$0.30 a share, said in a news release that it managed to maintain a high cash flow despite acquiring and absorbing Dun & Bradstreet Software Services Inc.
Lawrence said he was surprised since he had expected the company to barely break even on its operating results.

Another analyst, who declined to be identified, said the results were questionable given that Geac itself said its purchase of money-losing Dun & Bradstreet for US$150 million in cash and a US$41.25 million note was a little bit pricey.
"There's no way that (Geac) can turn it around in one quarter," the analyst said. "I'm very suspicious, very suspicious of what's behind all this."
Lawrence, who was more bullish, noted the write-down did not include cash.

Lawrence added that as a result of Geac's strong operating income he would increase his earnings estimates upward from his original C$2.44 a share and forecast the stock would be worth as much as C$60 by the end of calendar 1997.
